datafield.subfield: Rudolf Kolisch was a Viennese-American violinist and string quartet player. The collection contains thirty-one items, principally holograph manuscript correspondence, that provide insight into the professional relationship between Kolisch and composers Arnold Schoenberg, Alban Berg, and Anton Webern. Included among these are two Berg manuscripts that present analysis and musical examples from his Lyric suite and String quartet, op. 3.

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Rudolf Kolisch was a Viennese-American violinist and string quartet player. The collection contains thirty-one items, principally holograph manuscript correspondence, that provide insight into the professional relationship between Kolisch and composers Arnold Schoenberg, Alban Berg, and Anton Webern. Included among these are two Berg manuscripts that present analysis and musical examples from his Lyric suite and String quartet, op. 3.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Rudolf Kolisch Collection was processed in 2010 by Juliette Appold and encoded for EAD by Christopher Hartten.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright on the materials of the Rudolf Kolisch Collection is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Rudolf Kolisch Collection is open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Performing Arts Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: container number, Rudolf Kolisch Collection, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Rudolf Kolisch (1896-1978) was a prominent Viennese-American violinist and string quartet player who played his instrument left-handed as a result of a childhood injury. His Kolisch Quartet gave seminal performances and premieres of chamber music that included compositions by Arnold Schoenberg, Alban Berg, and Anton Webern. In 1935, Kolisch immigrated to the United States, where he developed a parallel career as a professor of music at the University of Wisconsin, the New England Conservatory of Music, and other institutions.

chronitem.event: Graduates from Vienna Music Academy and Vienna University
Plays a leading role in Schoenberg's "Verein für Musikalische Privataufführungen" (Society for Private Musical Performances)
Forms the Wiener Streichquartett (Rudolf Kolisch, Fritz Rothschild, Marcel Dick, Joachim Stutschewsky)
Arnold Schoenberg marries Kolisch's sister, Gertrud
Forms the Kolisch Quartett (Rudolf Kolisch, Felix Khuner, Eugene Lehner, Benar Heifetz)
Kolisch Quartett immigrates to the United States and makes its American debut performance at the Library of Congress
Begins teaching at the New School for Social Research, New York
Publishes his best known article, Tempo and character in Beethoven's music
Becomes first violinist of Pro Arte Quartet
Begins teaching at the University of Wisconsin
Teaches at the Akademie für Tonkunst and Ferienkurse für neue Musik in Darnstadt, Germany
Begins teaching at the New England Conservatory of Music, Boston
Teaches chamber music performance at the annual Schoenberg Seminars in Mödling, Austria

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Rudolf Kolisch Collection contains thirty-one items, principally manuscript correspondence, that provide insight into the professional relationship between Kolisch and composers Arnold Schoenberg, Alban Berg, and Anton Webern, from 1921-1943. The Musical Analysis and Examples series includes materials related to Berg's Lyric suite and String quartet, op. 3. The Correspondence series consists of postcards and letters, chiefly from Webern to Kolisch, that discuss compositional progress and upcoming performances. Among the works mentioned are Webern's String trio, op. 20, String quartet, op. 28, Six bagatelles, op. 9, Fünf Sätze, op. 5, Symphony, op. 21, and Variations for piano, op. 27, as well as various compositions by Schoenberg, Berg, and Beethoven.

arrangement.head: Organization of the Rudolf Kolisch Collection
arrangement.p: The Rudolf Kolisch Collection is organized in 3 series:

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript in ink, with additions in pencil; [9] p.

note.p: Principally tone rows and scales from movements nos. 1-6 with analytical commentary

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript with music in ink and text in pencil; [2] p.

note.p: 11 measures for String quartet, op. 3, (including an "ossia" line for violoncello) and 6 additional measures for one unspecified instrument
Both pages contain questions and comments concerning performance practice and playability

did.physdesc: Typescript letter with notes in pencil; [2] p.

note.p: Contents: expresses thanks for a gift; mentions work on "Counterpoint"; discusses RK's essay on tempo markings in Beethoven; asks if RK considered performing his "Ode"; asks for the source of a Beethoven quote

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript postcard in black ink

note.p: Contents: expresses thanks for a gift; mentions Schoenberg and his [AW's] orchestration of Schoenberg's "Glückliche Hand" for chamber orchestra

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript postcard in black ink

note.p: Contents: mentions sending his music for printing to Universal Edition; references "Trio" premiere on Oct. 1

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript postcard in black ink

note.p: Contents: references "Trio" premiere on Oct. 1 and Universal Edition

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript postcard in black ink

note.p: Contents: references "Trio" performance on Oct. 1; responds to RK's concern of not being able to play; asks RK to return the original score if possible

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript postcard in black ink

note.p: Contents: mentions "Bagatellen" and performance suggestions for the work; references "Trio" performance in Cologne

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript postcard in black ink

note.p: Contents: mentions "Trio" performance in Siena; RK's pleusiry; Fr. Herlinger; performance of an evening song recital in London

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript postcard blue-purple pencil

note.p: Contents: mentions possible meeting with RK in Aussee

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript postcard in black ink

note.p: Contents: mentions performance of "Trio" in Siena and possible meeting in Aussee

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript postcard in black ink

note.p: Contents: mentions rescheduled choir rehearsal and possible meeting

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [2] p.

note.p: Contents: encourages RK to stay with the theater; mentions Schoenberg

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [2] p.

note.p: Contents: mentions performance opportunity mediated by Loos, suggesting the first "Quartet" and "Violinstücke"

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [1] p.

note.p: Contents: mentions accompanying letter of recommendation for Fr. Rosanska to Koussevitzki [missing]; discusses possible rehearsal date of Schoenberg's "Suite"

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [2] p.

note.p: Contents: mentions possible premiere of "Trio" at the end of Nov.; references "Bagatellen" and Schoenberg

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [2] p.

note.p: Contents: expresses thanks to RK, Mr. Khuner, and Heifetz for a great first performance of "Trio"

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [2] p.

note.p: Contents: mentions "Trio" and issues with A.D.M.V. and city of Schwerin concerning an upcoming performance

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [1] p.

note.p: Contents: summarizes aforementioned issue with Schwerin/A.D.M.V.; references accompanying response letter [missing]

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [1] p.

note.p: Contents: mentions his involvement with the radio station Ravag and invites RK to perform a cycle of contemporary chamber music, specifically quartets by Schoenberg

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [2] p.

note.p: Contents: mentions "5 Sätze" and "Quartet"; references to Schoenberg, Beethoven, Ast, Ms. Herlinger, Frl. Michalski, and Frl. Rozanska

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [2] p.

note.p: Contents: mentions gala event for Schoenberg ("Schoenberg-Feier") in the "Verein für neue Musik"; references to Jalowetz, Steuermann, and Stein; asks if RK can play "Quartet I and III" for the occasion

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [3] p.

note.p: Contents: mentions success of RK's quartet in the U.S.; talks about "Verein für neue Musik" and Schoenberg gala event that will feature his latest "Quartet" and "Waldtaube", with Klemperer conducting "Streicher-Suite"; references to Berg's violin concerto, his own symphony; completion of a variation composition for piano and work on a string quartet; mentions Peter and Steuermann

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [2] p.

note.p: Contents: references messages from London and discusses public performance of his "Quartet IV" by RK in Vienna; suggests Berg's "Quartet" for performance and mentions possibility of Steuermann playing his "Variationen"; asks for possible dates for performances

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black-blue ink; [2] p.

note.p: Contents: mentions possible meeting the following Monday in Vienna and RK's quartet performance of his "5 Stücke"

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [2] p.

note.p: Contents: mentions "Wind quintet" and "Quartet"; references to RK's performance of the "5 Sätze" in New York, E.S. Coolidge, and Schoenberg

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [4] p.

note.p: Contents: description and analysis of his String quartet, op. 28 in folder entitled: "Analyse Streichquartett"

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [2] p.

note.p: Contents: mentions Schoenberg, E. S. Coolidge, Boosey and Hawkes, Steuermann, daughter Christl and grand-daughter; discussion of first performance of "Quartet" (Sept. 22) and a later performance in NY (Nov. 1); talks about possibly recording the "Quartet"

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [2] p.

note.p: Contents: mentions his "Quartet", work on a symphony, Greissle, Steuermann, and financial matters

did.physdesc: Holograph manuscript letter in black ink; [1] p.

note.p: Contents: mentions Coolidge Medal, Schoenberg, an upcoming performance of his [AW's] "Quartet" in Warsaw, and work on a symphony with text by Hildegard Jone [op. 29]

did.physdesc: Crayon; [2] boards
